NATO has adapted to the changing global security landscape in various ways in recent years. Some of the ways in which NATO has adapted include:

1. Enhanced focus on collective defense: NATO has placed increased emphasis on its collective defense posture since the 2014 annexation of Crimea by Russia. The organization has increased its military presence in Eastern Europe and adopted a more assertive deterrence posture.

2. New partnerships and collaborations: NATO has formed new partnerships and collaborations with non-member countries and organizations to address emerging security challenges. For example, NATO has partnered with the European Union on issues such as cybersecurity and hybrid warfare.

3. Investment in advanced technologies: NATO continues to invest in advanced technologies to enhance its military capabilities, including those related to cybersecurity, missile defense, and autonomous systems.

4. Focus on counterterrorism: NATO has increased its focus on counterterrorism measures and capacity building in partner countries to address the threat posed by terrorist groups, such as ISIS.

5. Increased cooperation with industry: NATO has fostered closer cooperation with the defense industry to rapidly develop and deploy new technologies to meet emerging security threats.

Overall, NATO has adapted to the changing global security landscape by strengthening its collective defense, forming new partnerships and collaborations, investing in advanced technologies, focusing on counterterrorism, and increasing cooperation with the defense industry.
